Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Life Cycle of the Quasi Two-Day Wave in the Southern Hemisphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Coupling, Energetics, and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions (CEDAR) program, a broad-based, community-guided, upper atmospheric research program, is aimed at understanding the behavior of atmospheric regions from the lower atmosphere upward through the ionized upper layers of the atmosphere. One of the major themes of this program is the measurement of the transfer of atmospheric wave energy from the lower atmosphere into the mesosphere and lower thermosphere, which overlaps the lower ionosphere. An important dynamical phenomenon associated with this wave coupling is called the quasi two-day wave (QTDW), which is a large-scale wave structure seen in the middle atmosphere winds and temperatures that is particularly pronounced within the southern hemisphere region with a spatial extent over many thousands of km. The lifetime of this structure varies between one and two weeks with a rapid growth, evolution, and decay profile that is not understood. The research of this award would utilize simultaneous data from two NASA satellites to follow the spatial progression with longitude of this structure with high temporal resolution. The 10 years extent of the database will allow this phenomenon to be intercompared from year to year and for the two periods of solar maximum and solar minimum. This research would determine through the application of a theoretical primitive equation model what might be the predominant excitation source generating this wave structure. Two possible candidates would be investigated. One (baroclinic instability) is the development of a dynamical instability mechanism energized by the poleward edge of the stratospheric jet stream. The other (inertial instability) is an instability process energized near the geographic equator as a result of the very weak magnitude of the Coriolis force. The broader impact of this award is the improvement of our overall understanding of fundamental MLT dynamics. A graduate student would receive half-time support.

The proposed activity will directly address questions regarding the coupling between atmospheric height regions, and possible energetics feedbacks between the QTDW wave phenomenology and the zonal mean circulation. The QTDW structure will be holistically investigated from the generation region into the 110 km region. Momentum and energy exchange across the stratopause and mesopause boundaries will be examined. The study will encompass a decade of observations, 2002-present, which will allow study of contrasting years, e.g., the possible influence of stratospheric warmings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Planetary waves in Earth’s atmosphere are large-scale disturbances (~1,000 to 40,000 km wavelengths) that arise from diverse sources such as regional- or continental-scale terrain, land-ocean temperature contrasts, and large-scale horizontal and vertical wind shears at altitudes from the surface to ~100 km. Planetary waves at smaller scales, from ~1,000 to 5,000 km wavelengths, account for the jet streams and frontal systems that bring us our variable weather. Planetary waves having larger wavelengths can also impact weather, especially via events called sudden stratospheric warmings, where they reverse or displace the global-scale circulation, especially in the northern winter hemisphere stratosphere, with influences over a month or more that extend down to Earth’s surface.

Larger-scale planetary waves arising via unstable shear flows at higher altitudes can likewise have major effects on atmospheric circulation and structure at higher altitudes that nonetheless can also have measureable effects extending to Earth’s surface. One of these wave types, the quasi-2-day wave (or Q2DW), is usually comprised of several different wave modes having from 1 to 4 wavelengths around the planet (and one mode that has no variability in longitude), but a similar ~2-day period (hence the name). 

The Q2DW exhibits different modal composition and character in the northern and southern hemispheres because of different zonal jet structures. The northern hemisphere Q2DW exhibits significant variability throughout the summer season. The southern hemisphere Q2DW, in contrast, typically exhibits a single maximum occurrence near or shortly following summer solstice, and can induce large-scale winds that dominate atmospheric motions at altitudes above ~80 km.

The study performed in our research effort focused on a Q2DW event in January 2015 for which radars measuring winds from ~80-100-km altitudes at eight S. Hemisphere locations and satellite measurements enabling estimates of global Q2DW temperature and wind fields over the S. Hemisphere enabled a close comparison of the ground-based and satellite-based measurement capabilities. These revealed close agreement in the wind fields where radar data was highly confident, and inferences of the model composition and spatial and temporal variability of the Q2DW as a result. This enabled the first full identification of all contributing Q2DW modes, and assessments of their sources and influences on the upper atmosphere circulation and structure as a result. A research paper describing these results is available at https://doi.org/10.1029/2018JD029728
